answers.answer: Although HCV carries a lot of risks I don't think that was what he died from. Like was said, he had diabetes, a liver transplant and a kidney transplant and lung cancer. Mike
Goodmorning,Always liked his song, wasted days and wasted nites.A sad ending for a ole 70's jukebox honky tonker!!

I cant help but believe, Heck, we all know that most who die from Hep C do not die FROM Hep C.  This disease can cause so many other things that get listed as the cause of death.  Liver Cancer, Kidney Cancer, or the body wears down from Hep C itself, or the effects of tx and we become candidates for heart problems, diabetes and a host of auto immunes problems.  The root cause to many of these is Hep C and if listed as cause of death would have a lot more people interested in Hepatitis C.
He had actually been doing HCV awareness spots here in Texas. The PSAs could have been produced a little better, but he did them with dignity and was the best spokesperson I've seen so far.

Hope you both are hanging in there. Dyce, you are done soon aren't you? now that deserves some good Honky Tonkin' tunes! Who could forget that song, dyce man. How about "Until the Next Teardrop Falls" another one of his hits. He sure got a lot done in his like for someone who had a lot he was dealing with. I was glad they mentioned HCV as a contribution. Often times it is not mentioned and as you said Eyedeas it most likely is one of the starting points for some of his ailments. Drug/alcohol abuse was a contributor too but he rehabbed in the early 80's I read. In spite of his struggles with a lot of illness and addiction issues, he rocked and accomplished a lot in his life. He got thrown in Angola for 3 years for a couple joints. His real name was Baldemar G. Huerta.Descanse En Paz
I tend to agree with Mike Simon here. Sounds like he had a lot of health issues with Hep C simply one of them, not necessarily the cause of the others.
...nor the cause of his death. May he rest in peace.

Just want to say that my father's death certificate said heart failure as the cause of death.  He had cancer of the nasopharnix area and underwent chemotherapy and radiation unsuccessfully and without the rescue drugs available now.  No doubt in my mind it was a combo of the cancer and tx that took him from us.Freddie played a part in my life and will live on thru his music.miss

Thanks for asking, got 15 more shots to go. Did 33 fri. and although the anemia is under control , the peg still likes to perform it's dance on sat and sundays.My sx's are easier to go with now but I had to slow myself back down there cause when the procrit kicked in I was a spinning top. So 15 more weeks of still take it easier at work til I get thru this!!

ooohhhhhhhhh nnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnooooooooooooooi love him and had heard the other day about him but, didn't know he died.  oh i'm so sad!  On cbs news here in s.a.,tx they said he had a transplant and was rushed back to s.a. due to a complication on a serios blood illness. god bless his family and all that loved him.  (my favorite since i met you baby)

The liver has such a big place in the immune system that hep c can be the underlying cause of just about any massive infection that can cause death.  Hep c is probably undiagnosed in ostensibly healthy people who just suddenly die of massive infections.I had a beta strep infection invade my large intestine in 1999; 16 inches of my bowel was removed and I went into sepsis and multi-organ failure, with eight days of coma and not expected to live.  I was not diagnosed with hep c until a couple of months after this event.  If I had died, hep c would not have been listed as a cause of death, even though cirrhosis caused by hep c is what allowed the infection to proliferate in the first place.

Here is one article from Chest magazine on the possible connection between hepatitis C and Lung disease.  Chest magazine has done 3 articles in recent years.  Once you find this one you can find the related ones.  You can print out the old ones but have to pay for the new one (2006).  I found it in my hospital's library.http://www.chestjournal.org/cgi/content/full/123/2/596

I tend to agree with you both...I think that HCV causes far more deaths than ever realized, and probably is overlooked in many of them...especially if they are heart, stroke, diabetes, or infection related.  I fully believe that HCV erodes many organs and systems over time causing things like coronary weakness, heart problems, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, stroke, lymphoma, liver cancer, and other also I would suspect.  This disease has been directly linked to several serious diseases, and is being looked at in a wide variety of other ailments.  I really think the consequences of unchecked HCV progression involves far, far more than just liver disease or HCC.  I believe that this is a multifaceted, system wide, and even organ wide disease.  Science is just opening up the doors to understanding this recently emerging virus, and we only know the tip of the iceberg at this point, in my opinion.Research is moving quickly (finally) and in ten to fifteen years I think we will know much more about what we really have on our hands,  I pray that by then we will have eight or ten targeted drugs in our arsenal that will be quantum leaps more effective than the current Inf./Riba based therapies...and possibly, just possibly will fully, totally, and unquestionably eradicate the virus from all locations.  That is a real stretch to hope for, but science is moving quickly, and breakthrough therapies are emerging.  Lets all support and push for medical advancement in the HCV arena.  Gos knows, AIDS, Cancer, Diabetes, and a ton of other diseases get constant, high profile attention from all the politicians, entertainers, and wealthy corporate sponsors!We could use some of that attention, and the research dollars!!!!DoubleDose

yo bro !!..just know that the time ain't wasted day or nite..but SVR!!.....hang tuff & take it easy on yourself...listen to some ol jimmie rodgers -' just waiting for a train'..that riba express gonna take you home

About 75% done.  That's got to sound like a good number to you.  Just keep plugging away.  Glad to hear anemia/procrit is in balance.  Which peg you use Pegasys or PegIntron? My worst days we the shot weekends too.

I certainly didn't intend to minimize the impact HCV has on our overall health. Freddy's case is pretty complicated. Since he was transplanted for kidney and liver he was almost certainly taking anti-rejction meds and that increases the risk of cancer. I don't think we can separate HCV out of the equation. But with as many issues as Freddy had it might be pushing it to say that hepatitis was the cause of his death. Mike

Thanks for asking there dude, Ya I can see the end coming sooner everyday now. Seems like we been on this tx forever!Some hard livin when that hmg dipped down but now I can get out and do some work again.Pegasus 180 mg , 1200 riba a day. I don't know how but haven't missed a dose yet.How bout you, I'm not sure but your meds. arrived last tues. right.
There were a couple of speed bumps.  They are in shipment today, get them tomorrow. Will start in two weeks, have a business trip next week that I can't screw up.

question: I read the headline "Freddy Fender dies of cancer" but in the LA Times if you read on, he had Hep C.Sadly, we have yet another great talent lost to this disease.
title: Freddy Fender dies , had Hep C
